Bst

Rich

yamaimojg wrote:

> Rich,
> All that I can make out is tadashige. As you no doubt already know
> there were both Joshu Umetada Tadashige and Shigemasa working in about
> the right time period. The workmanship looks right for Umetada.
>
> I don't know much about Goshu Hikone Tadashige, but at least some of
> his work is in classic Soten style. I can't say that I've seen
> Soten/Hikone work in the style of your tsuba.
>
> Jim
>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: more on the Soten/Umetada tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, All that I can make out is tadashige.  As you no doubt already know there were both Joshu Umetada Tadashige and Shigemasa working in about the right time
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
All that I can make out is tadashige. As you no doubt already know
there were both Joshu Umetada Tadashige and Shigemasa working in about
the right time period. The workmanship looks right for Umetada.

I don't know much about Goshu Hikone Tadashige, but at least some of
his work is in classic Soten style. I can't say that I've seen
Soten/Hikone work in the style of your tsuba.

Jim

wrote:

> monitor. Sorry to here about it's holiday.
>
> Rich
>
>
> Jim Gilbert wrote:
>
> > Rich,
> > The kanji for sei is è£½ and is a suffix meaning "made." It's a
common
> > ending for Soten signatures.

messages.msgSnippet: ... they gifted it to I will take another look. Funny you should mention that.  Recently out of the blue FedEx delivered a flat panel display that I didn t
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> wrote:
> As soon as FedEx retrieves my new flat panel display from whomever
they gifted it to I will take another look.

Funny you should mention that. Recently out of the blue FedEx
delivered a flat panel display that I didn't order from anyone. Works
really slick, too. I'll never go back to a CRT. Hahahahaha!!!

NC ;o)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] more on the Soten/Umetada tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The kanji for sei is 製 and is a suffix meaning made.  It s a common ending for Soten signatures. I haven t been able to make out anything from your
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The kanji for sei is 製 and is a suffix meaning "made." It's a common ending for Soten signatures.

I haven't been able to make out anything from your signature, but my monitor is in a sorry state. As soon as FedEx retrieves my new flat panel display from whomever they gifted it to I will take another look.

Jim
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, June 12, 2005 11:05 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] more on the Soten/Umetada tsuba


I have had one opinion, that it could be Tadashige sei".The right part
could be (a guess only) "Goshu Hikone ju". Now I see nothing of Soten in
this tsuba but I am totally lost on this one so I could well be wrong.
Also, I am unfaliuar with the term Sei, and it's meaning in this case,
also, the kanji for it. Can anyone help there please.

Cheers

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book title identification
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, that s Joly s hand copy taken from an old edition.  There is another modern version in print from a different hand copy. Jim The Toban Shinpin Zukan is
messages.messageBody:
Yes, that's Joly's hand copy taken from an old edition. There is another modern version in print from a different hand copy.

Jim



The Toban Shinpin Zukan is being reprinted in serial form and is
currently included in the mailings of the Northern California Japanese
Sword Club. For some reason the pages aren't numbered, but there are
two tsuba per plate and so far they are up to plate 155.

Bob

Jim Gilbert wrote:
> David,
> There's a Toban Shinpin Zukan (zuroku) published in the 1780's. I don't
> think that the author's name is known.
>
> Why do you ask?
>
> Jim
>
>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book title identification
messages.msgSnippet: This would presumably be: Matsumiya Toshiyori (Kanzan), Tôban Fu (or Tôban Zufu), (original before 1740), copy 1753, Tôban Shinpin Zukan, copy date? It
messages.messageBody:
This would presumably be:

Matsumiya Toshiyori (Kanzan), Tôban Fu (or Tôban Zufu), (original before 1740), copy 1753, Tôban Shinpin Zukan, copy date?

It would be one of the titles thought to have influenced Akiyama Kyusaku.

David


----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, May 29, 2005 8:48 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book title identification


David,
There's a Toban Shinpin Zukan (zuroku) published in the 1780's. I don't think that the author's name is known.

Why do you ask?

Jim




Can anyone identify this title by author & date, or correct the spelling : Shin-Pin Suroku?
